Green Networking Metrics Green Networking Metrics
draft-cx-opsawg-green-metrics-00 draft-cx-opsawg-green-metrics-01
Abstract Abstract
This document explains the need for network instrumentation that This document explains the need for network instrumentation that
allows to assess the power consumption, energy efficiency, and carbon allows to assess a number of sustainability-related attributes such
footprint associated with a network, its equipment, and the services as power consumption, energy efficiency, and carbon footprint
that are provided over it. It also suggests a set of related metrics associated with a network, its equipment, and the services that are
that, when provided visibility into, can help to optimize a network's provided over it. It also suggests a set of related metrics that,
when provided visibility into, can help to optimize a network's
"greenness" accordingly. "greenness" accordingly.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Climate change and the need to curb greenhouse emissions have been Climate change and the need to curb greenhouse emissions have been
recognized by the United Nations and by most governments as one of recognized by the United Nations and by many governments as one of
the biggest and most urgent challenges of our time [unipcc2023]. As the biggest and most urgent challenges of our time [UN-IPCC-2023].
a result, reducing carbon footprint is becoming of increasing As a result, reducing carbon footprint is becoming of increasing
importance for society and all industries. The networking industry importance for society and all industries. The networking industry
is no exception. is no exception.
Networks themselves consume significant amounts of energy and thus Networks themselves consume significant amounts of energy and thus
contribute to greenhouse emissions. Therefore, the networking contribute to greenhouse emissions. Therefore, the networking
industry has an important role to play in meeting sustainability industry has an important role to play in meeting sustainability
goals. Future networking advances will increasingly need to focus on goals. Future networking advances will increasingly need to focus on
becoming more sustainable and reducing carbon footprint, both for becoming more sustainable and reducing carbon footprint, both for
economic reasons and for reasons of corporate responsibility. Those economic reasons and for reasons of corporate social responsibility.
advances will focus first and foremost on greater energy efficiency, Those advances initially focus on improving energy efficiency and
but not be limited to that. Other factors include consideration for will continue in several other areas. Of equivalent important is how
how power is being sourced (e.g. carbon versus solar based), power is being sourced (e.g., carbon versus solar based). Other
considerations for the lifecycle of hardware (e.g. software versus factors include considerations for the lifecycle of hardware (e.g.,
forklift upgrades), and considerations related to deployments (for embedded carbon during material extraction and manufacturing,
transportation, software versus forklift upgrades, consumption of
cloud-delivered), and considerations related to deployments (for
example, minimizing the "energy tax" associated with heating or example, minimizing the "energy tax" associated with heating or
cooling of networking devices). This shift has already begun and cooling of networking devices). This shift has already begun, and
sustainability is well on its way towards becoming an important sustainability is well on its way towards becoming an important
concern for network providers [telefonica2021]. concern for network providers [Telefonica2021].
A broader underlying background and analysis on sustainability
considerations for networking can be found at
[I-D.cparsk-eimpact-sustainability-considerations].
There are many vectors along which networks can be made "greener". There are many vectors along which networks can be made "greener".
At its foundation, it involves network equipment itself. For At its foundation, it involves network equipment itself. For
example, making such equipment more energy-efficient is a big factor example, making such equipment more energy-efficient is a big factor
in helping networks become greener. However, opportunities also in helping networks become greener. However, opportunities also
exist at the level of protocols themselves (e.g. reduction of exist at the level of protocols themselves (e.g., reduction of
transmission waste and enabling of rapid control loops), at the level transmission waste and enabling of rapid control loops), at the level
of the overall network (e.g. path optimization under consideration of of the overall network (e.g., path optimization under consideration
energy efficiency as a cost factor), and architecture level (e.g. of energy efficiency as a cost factor), and architecture level (e.g.,
placement of contents and functions) [I.D.draft-cwx-green-ps]. placement of contents and functions) [I-D.cx-green-ps].
Regardless of any particular approach that is chosen, in order to Regardless of any particular approach that is chosen, in order to
assess its impact, there is a need to have visibility. For example, assess its impact, there is a need to have visibility. For example,
techniques that attempt to minimize energy consumption may need techniques that attempt to minimize energy consumption may need
visiblity into the actual energy consumption that is occurring in a visibility into the actual energy consumption that is occurring in a
network and to ideally be able to attribute that consumption to what network and to ideally be able to attribute that consumption to what
is causing it. As the adage goes, you cannot manage what you cannot is causing it. As the adage goes, you cannot manage what you cannot
measure. By extension, you cannot optimize what you have no measure. By extension, you cannot optimize what you have no
visibility of. The ability to instrument networks in a way that visibility of. The ability to instrument networks in a way that
allows for the assessment of factors related to a network's allows for the assessment of factors related to a network's
environmental footprint is hence an important enabler for potential environmental footprint is hence an important enabler for potential
optimizations that help to reduce that footprint. Not only does it optimizations that help to reduce that footprint. Not only does it
allow to assess the effectiveness of measures that are being taken, allow to assess the effectiveness of measures being taken, but it
it also enables (for example) control loops based on those factors. also enables (for example) control loops based on those factors.
Before instrumenting, it needs to be clear, however, what the proper Before instrumenting, it needs to be clear, however, what the proper
metrics are that network providers will be interested in and that metrics are that network providers will be interested in and that
applications will seek to optimize. applications will seek to optimize.
This document defines a set of metrics that allow to assess the This document defines a set of metrics that allow to assess the
"greenness" of networks and that form the basis for optimizing energy "greenness" of networks and that form the basis for optimizing energy
efficiency, carbon footprint, and environmental sustainability of efficiency, carbon footprint, and environmental sustainability of
networks and the services provided. These metrics are intended to networks and the services provided. These metrics are intended to
serve the foundation for possible later IETF standardization serve the foundation for possible later IETF standardization
activities, such as the definition of related YANG modules [RFC7950] activities, such as the definition of related YANG modules [RFC7950]
or energy-related control protocol extensions. It should be noted or energy-related control protocol extensions. It should be noted
that the metrics introduced here are not intended to be used to that the metrics introduced here are not intended to be used to
manage applications such as Power over Ethernet, requirements and manage applications such as Power over Ethernet, requirements and
instrumentation for which have been defined in other contexts (e.g. instrumentation for which have been defined in other contexts (e.g.,
[RFC6988][RFC7460]). [RFC6988][RFC7460]).

from a single other metric by applying a conversion formula associated with the use of technology, usually directly correlated
with the associated energy consumption

which it can be computed (or "derived")

consumption in a way that reflects also the power consumption of consumption in a way that also reflects the power consumption of
the overall deployment including non-network equipment such as the overall deployment including non-network equipment such as
cooling. cooling.

source PSF: Power Sustainability Factor, a factor used to weigh power

consumption metrics in order to account for factors such as the consumption metrics in order to account for factors such as the

3. Green Metrics 3. Green Metrics
In the following, we categorize green metrics according to the In the following, we categorize green metrics according to the
subject of the metrics, as follows: subject of the metrics, as follows:
* At the device/equipment level. This concerns aspects such as * At the device/equipment level. This concerns aspects such as
energy consumption of a device as a whole, of equipment components energy consumption of a device as a whole, of equipment components
such as line cards or individual ports. It includes metrics that such as line cards or individual ports.
would, for example, be found in equipment data sheets.
* At the flow level. This concerns metrics that can be attributed * At the flow level. This concerns metrics that can be attributed
to flows. For example, this includes metrics that attribute a to flows. For example, this includes metrics that could attribute
device's share of its carbon footprint to a given flow, or metrics a device's share of its carbon footprint to a given flow, or
that aggregate energy consumption of packets across the flow. metrics that aggregate energy consumption of packets across the
flow. A flow is defined as per the IPFIX [RFC7011] context.
* At the path level. These metrics attest to the end-to-end carbon * At the path level. These metrics attest to the end-to-end green
footprint of paths, reflecting for example the amount of energy metrics of paths, reflecting for example the amount of energy
drawn when the path is selected, taking into account the energy drawn when the path is selected, taking into account the energy
efficiency and sustainability ratings of path segments across the efficiency and sustainability ratings of path segments across the
path. path.
* At the network level. These metrics aggregate sustainability * At the network domain level. These metrics aggregate
metrics across a network to provide a holistic picture of the sustainability metrics across a network domain to provide a
"network as a system". For example, this includes energy consumed holistic picture of the "network domain as a system". For
by the network as a whole and may account also for aspects such as example, this includes energy consumed by the network as a whole
the overall energy mix. and may account also for aspects such as the overall energy mix.
Topological considerations are important at the network domain
level.
The green metrics that are defined are mostly comprised of energy The green metrics that are defined are mostly comprised of energy
metrics, as required to assess and optimize various aspects of energy metrics, as required to assess, and optimize various aspects of
consumption and efficiency. However, those energy metrics are energy consumption and efficiency. However, those energy metrics are
complemented by certain other metrics, for example metrics that complemented by certain other metrics, for example metrics that
account for the sustainability of the energy source (where known). account for the sustainability of the energy source (where known).
We furthermore distinguish between primary metrics which are directly We furthermore distinguish between primary metrics which are directly
measured, and derived metrics which are computed from multiple measured, and derived metrics which are computed from multiple
factors. For example, a primary metric might be the power factors. For example, a primary metric might be the power
consumption of a device, while a derived metric might be a metric consumption of a device, while a derived metric might be a metric
that relates energy consumption to utility provided, for example that relates energy consumption to utility provided, for example

3.1.1. Energy Consumption Metrics 3.1.1. Energy Consumption Metrics
Arguably the most relevant green metrics relate to equipment. After Arguably the most relevant green metrics relate to equipment. After
all, power is drawn from devices. all, power is drawn from devices.
The power consumption of the device can be divided into the The power consumption of the device can be divided into the
consumption of the core components (e.g., the backplane and CPU) as consumption of the core components (e.g., the backplane and CPU) as
well as additional consumption incurred per port and line card. In well as additional consumption incurred per port and line card. In
[I.D.draft-manral-bmwg-power-usage], the device factors affecting [I-D.manral-bmwg-power-usage], the device factors affecting power
power consumption are summarized: base chassis power, number of line consumption are summarized: base chassis power, number of line cards,
cards, number of active ports, port settings, port utilization, number of active ports, port settings, port utilization,
implementation of packet classification of Ternary Content- implementation of packet classification of Ternary Content-
Addressable Memory (TCAM) and the size of TCAM, firmware version. Addressable Memory (TCAM) and the size of TCAM, firmware version.
Furthermore it is important to understand the difference between Furthermore, it is important to understand the difference between
power consumption when a resource is idling versus when it is under power consumption when a resource is idling versus when it is under
load. This helps to understand the incremental cost of additional load. This helps to understand the incremental cost of additional
transmission versus the initial cost of transmission. Generally, the transmission versus the initial cost of transmission. Generally, the
cost of the first bit could be considered very high, as it requires cost of the first bit could be considered very high, as it requires
powering up a device, port, etc. The cost of transmission of powering up a device, port, etc. The cost of transmission of
additional bits (beyond the first) is many orders of magnitude lower. additional bits (beyond the first) is many orders of magnitude lower.
Likewise, the incremental cost of CPU and memory that will be needed Likewise, the incremental cost of CPU and memory that will be needed
to process additional packets becomes fairly negligible. to process additional packets becomes negligible.
The first set of metrics corresponds to energy ratings of the device. The first set of metrics corresponds to energy ratings of the device.

deployments or optimization of configuration of paths. They also deployments or optimization of configuration of paths. They also
provide a good proxy to model expected actual energy use in a provide a good proxy to model expected actual energy use in a
network. network.

* Power consumption when fully loaded (e.g. Watts) * Power consumption when fully loaded (e.g., Watts)

utilization, power consumption at 90% utilization utilization, power consumption at 90% utilization

from the earlier metrics. They normalize the power consumption from the earlier metrics. They normalize the power consumption
relative to the line speeds respectively to the amount of traffic relative to the line speeds respectively to the amount of traffic
that is being passed. Rather than assessing absolute power that is being passed. Rather than assessing absolute power
consumption, they relate power consumed to functionality provided in consumption, they relate power consumed to functionality provided in

Accordingly, as metrics, the following are being proposed: Accordingly, as metrics, the following are being proposed:
* Power Sustainability Factor (PSF). This factor reflects the * Power Sustainability Factor (PSF). This factor reflects the
sustainability of the energy mix that is used to power the device. sustainability of the energy mix that is used to power the device.
When multiplied with actual power consumption, it can provide a When multiplied with actual power consumption, it can provide a
"weighted" power consumption that accounts for (for example) the "weighted" power consumption that accounts for (for example) the
portion of energy that is renewable. portion of energy that is renewable. This is typically referred
to as Carbon Intensity, or Electricity emission factor.
* Deployment Sustainability Factor (DSF). This factor reflects a * Deployment Sustainability Factor (DSF). This factor reflects a
factor to attribute a share of a deployment's overall power factor to attribute a share of a deployment's overall power
consumption (beyond that directly caused by networking devices) to consumption (beyond that directly caused by networking devices) to
individual network devices. individual network devices.

footprint is minimized, then applying techniques such as path-aware footprint is minimized, then applying techniques such as path-aware

segment routing [RFC8402] to steer traffic along those paths that are routing [RFC8402] to steer traffic along those paths that are deemed
deemed "the greenest" among alternatives. It also includes aspects "the greenest" among alternatives. It also includes aspects such as

decisions, as has been suggested in proposals for energy-aware and been suggested in proposals for energy-aware and pollution-aware
pollution-aware networking [Hossain2019]. networking [Hossain2019].

existing mechanisms can be leveraged for greener networking simply by existing mechanisms can be leveraged for greener networking simply by
introducing energy footprint as a cost factor. Low-hanging fruit introducing energy footprint as a cost factor. Low-hanging fruit
includes the inclusion of energy-related parameters as a cost includes the inclusion of energy-related parameters as a cost
parameter in control planes, whether distributed (e.g. IGP) or parameter in control planes, whether distributed (e.g., IGP) or
conceptually centralized via SDN controllers. conceptually centralized via SDN controllers.

such as paths involving intermediate routers that are powered by such as paths involving intermediate routers that are powered by
renewable energy resources might be considered, as might be renewable energy resources might be considered, as might be
determined by an aggregate sustainability score. After all, paths determined by an aggregate sustainability score. After all, paths
with devices that are powered by solar, wind, or geothermal might be with devices that are powered by solar, wind, or geothermal might be

3.4. Energy Metrics related to the Network-at-Large 3.4. Energy Metrics related to the Network-at-Large
Ultimately, the goal of energy optimization and reduction of carbon Ultimately, the goal of energy optimization and reduction of carbon
footprint is to minimize the aggregate amount of energy used across footprint is to minimize the aggregate amount of energy used across
the entire network, as well as to minimize the overall carbon the entire network, as well as to minimize the overall carbon
footprint of the network as a whole. Accordingly, metrics that footprint of the network as a whole. Accordingly, metrics that
aggregate the energy usage across the network as a whole are needed. aggregate the energy usage across the network as a whole are needed.
In order to account for changing traffic profiles, growth in user In order to account for changing traffic profiles, growth in user
traffic etc, additional metrics are needed that normalize the total traffic, etc., additional metrics are needed that normalize the total
over the volume of services supported and volume of traffic passed. over the volume of services supported and volume of traffic passed.
Corresponding metrics will generally be computed at the level of Corresponding metrics will generally be computed at the level of
Operational Support Systems (or Business Support Systems) for the Operational Support Systems (or Business Support Systems) for the
entire network. entire network.
Some of the metrics used include the following [telefonica2021]: Some of the metrics used include the following [Telefonica2021]:
* Total energy consumption (MWh) * Total energy consumption (MWh)
* Electricity from renewable sources (%) * Electricity from renewable sources (%)
* Network energy efficiency (MWh/PB) * Network energy efficiency (MWh/PB)

The network itself is only one contributor to a network's carbon The network itself is only one contributor to a network's carbon
footprint. Arguably just as important are aspects outside the footprint. Arguably just as important are aspects outside the
network itself, such as cooling and ventilation. These aspects need network itself, such as cooling and ventilation. These aspects need
to be taken into account as part of a holistic perspective. However, to be taken into account as part of a holistic perspective. However,
reflecting such aspects in detail would arguably result in "boiling reflecting such aspects in detail would arguably result in "boiling
the ocean" and are therefore not further addressed here. the ocean" and are therefore not further addressed here.

4.4. Dealing with imprecision and uncertainty 4.4. Dealing with imprecision and uncertainty
In some cases, it may be difficult to determine the values of metrics In some cases, it may be difficult to determine the values of metrics
precisely. This may be due to, for example, limitations of precisely. This may be due to, for example, limitations of
instrumentation and/or the fact that consumption of energy (for instrumentation and/or the fact that consumption of energy (for
example) is neither constant nor linear but adheres to more complex example) is neither constant nor linear but adheres to more complex
functions. In those cases, it may be advisable to allow for a way to functions. In those cases, it may be advisable to allow for a way to
express metrics in ways that allow to reflect a degree of express metrics in ways that allow to reflect a degree of
uncertainty. For example, power consumption can be addressed not as uncertainty. For example, power consumption can be addressed not as
a single value but as a range defined by an upper and lower bound, as a single value but as a range defined by an upper and lower bound, as
suggested e.g. in [Petrescu2010] for the expression of power suggested e.g., in [Petrescu2010] for the expression of power
consumption of links. consumption of links.

7. Security Considerations 7. Security Considerations
When instrumenting a network for energy metrics, it is important that When instrumenting a network for energy metrics, it is important that
implementations are secured to ensure that data is accurately implementations are secured to ensure that data is accurately
measured and cannot be tampered with. For example, an attacker might measured, communicated, and cannot be tampered with. For example, an
try to tamper energy readings to confuse controller trying to minize attacker might try to tamper energy readings to confuse controller
power consumption, leading to increased power consumption instead. trying to minimize power consumption, leading to increased power
In addition, access to the data needs to be secured in similar ways consumption instead. In addition, access to the data needs to be
as for other sensitive management data, for example using secure secured in similar ways as for other sensitive management data, for
management protocols and subjecting energy data that is maintained in example using secure management protocols and subjecting energy data
YANG datastores via NACM (NETCONF Access Control Model). that is maintained in YANG datastores via NACM (NETCONF Access
Control Model). Specifically, these metrics need to have signed
origin, traceability, and optional cryptographic protection.
However, it should be noted that this draft specifies only metrics However, it should be noted that this draft specifies only metrics
themselves, not how to instrument networks accordingly. For the themselves, not how to instrument networks accordingly. For the
definition of metrics themselves, security considerations do thus not definition of metrics themselves, security considerations do not
really apply. directly apply.
